DOCUMENT:
Tommy Mayhem bounced across the surface of the alien planet. Sparks flew from the tip of his lasergun as he blasted the attacking dinosaurs. Triumphantly, he jumped through the entrance to their lair, lasers booming.  "Tomas R. Fletcher, you stop that racket this instant!" his mother chided. Steven caught her next passing arm on her back and carefully pulled her up into a sitting position atop his shoulders. As the two young siblings sat, Jeanne climbed off her own parent and ran over. Her red hair was matted with dust, but she stood before them unscathed. She'd been transported about four feet away as they'd entered during Michael's short stint away. She grinned at both brothers, whose surprise passed quickly.

  choice: Her red hair was matted with dust, but she stood before them unscathed.
  choice: his mother chided.
  choice: She'd been transported about four feet away as they'd entered during Michael's short stint away.
  choice: She grinned at both brothers, whose surprise passed quickly.
  choice: Steven caught her next passing arm on her back and carefully pulled her up into a sitting position atop his shoulders.

targets: Steven caught her next passing arm on her back and carefully pulled her up into a sitting position atop his shoulders.
multiple_choice_targets: Tommy Mayhem bounced across the surface of the alien planet.
Sparks flew from the tip of his lasergun as he blasted the attacking dinosaurs.
Triumphantly, he jumped through the entrance to their lair, lasers booming.
"Tomas R. Fletcher, you stop that racket this instant!"
his mother chided.
Steven caught her next passing arm on her back and carefully pulled her up into a sitting position atop his shoulders.
As the two young siblings sat, Jeanne climbed off her own parent and ran over.
Her red hair was matted with dust, but she stood before them unscathed.
She'd been transported about four feet away as they'd entered during Michael's short stint away.
She grinned at both brothers, whose surprise passed quickly.

DOCUMENT:
SHAYNE LEWIS, a talented baseball player, had a choice: a full scholarship at Stanford University, or a shot at playing professional ball with the Chicago Cubs. Shayne's parents disagreed over what was best for their son. His father, Josh, wanted him to go pro. His mom, Reva, was more concerned with the boy's education. "I told her I didn't want him going to college," Reva says. "He should be in school." Reva Lewis is an educator and coach who has worked with hundreds of children from all walks of life. She knows that many kids are not ready for college. But she also believes that if you're willing to work hard, there is no limit to what you can achieve. So Reva decided to give Shayne a second chance.

DOCUMENT:
My father wanted me to become a priest. He would have settled for merchant son or even an academic. He repeatedly threatened to disinherit me. In the end, he gave in, and so paid for my commission. I was taken from the parish school into his office. The headmaster had already refused my admission after hearing about what happened to my father. "What did you tell him? "I told him: 'Father, this is not right. You should be ashamed of yourself. It was you who got us into trouble by telling lies.'

IT'S not the budget part that makes a $500 Washington weekend tough. It's their food. Here, I'll list some of their recommendations for when you can't find real or local. And even if we get to get out and eat at all the fine restaurants, don't let this discourage your spirit — eat well in Seattle while enjoying those lovely Memorial Day weekends! The Mushroom Cafe & Market: Ok, it isn't really in Seattle but there are still really good Thai restaurants around town — The Mushroom is just one of them. According to its website, the owner's daughters work there, and they bring back memories from growing up in the area (like cherry blossom petals). Check out the map below:

DOCUMENT:
I will apologize, my grammar and spelling is atrocious at best, I'm on my phone and I saw an opportunity to write. I stood atop the empire I had built, looking down at my loyal peons as the crawled from street to street and store to store, following about thier daily rituals. With each purchase they fuelled thier demise, I had spent much of my knowledge and time on building this empire from the depths of society. And soon once I had all of them within the grasp of my elaborate control I would crush them. But there was one small problem with my plan: in order for me to continue my conquest over them they must first be separated from their only source of sustenance. That would be food, they eat too much! I knew that if I could just get them out of that food store without any help I'd have a large army ready to slaughter every last individual there. Then after I got rid of everyone else I could finally kill those poor children and cut off their nutrition, or so I thought. Well it turns out that while I've been feeding them, they haven't eaten very well either.

targets: But there was one small problem with my plan: in order for me to continue my conquest over them they must first be separated from their only source of sustenance.
multiple_choice_targets: I will apologize, my grammar and spelling is atrocious at best, I'm on my phone and I saw an opportunity to write.
I stood atop the empire I had built, looking down at my loyal peons as the crawled from street to street and store to store, following about thier daily rituals.
With each purchase they fuelled thier demise, I had spent much of my knowledge and time on building this empire from the depths of society.
And soon once I had all of them within the grasp of my elaborate control I would crush them.
But there was one small problem with my plan: in order for me to continue my conquest over them they must first be separated from their only source of sustenance.
That would be food, they eat too much!
I knew that if I could just get them out of that food store without any help I'd have a large army ready to slaughter every last individual there.
Then after I got rid of everyone else
I could finally kill those poor children and cut off their nutrition, or so I thought.
Well it turns out that while I've been feeding them, they haven't eaten very well either.

DOCUMENT:
HOW TO MAKE: Pizza With Artichokes, Rosemary and Goat Cheese
Ingredients:
1 1/4 ounce packaged dry yeast
1 cup lukewarm water
2 1/2 cups high-gluten flour
1 teaspoon salt
4 tablespoons olive oil
1 pound baby artichokes
1 clove garlic, green part removed, minced
1 medium onion, sliced
1 tablespoon rosemary leaves
Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
3 ounces goat cheese
3 tablespoons pine nuts. Make the pizza dough. Combine the yeast with one-quarter cup of the water. Cover and leave until doubled in volume. If the mixture does not rise, throw it away and use a fresh package of yeast. If working by hand, combine the flour and salt and place on a smooth work surface. Stir in the garlic and rosemary. Cook for another minute. Add the artichoke hearts, stir and cook for an additional 3 minutes. Remove from heat and transfer to a bowl.
  choice: Remove from heat and transfer to a bowl.
  choice: Combine the yeast with one-quarter cup of the water.
  choice: If the mixture does not rise, throw it away and use a fresh package of yeast.
  choice: Add the artichoke hearts, stir and cook for an additional 3 minutes.
  choice: Make the pizza dough.
  choice: Cook for another minute.
  choice: Stir in the garlic and rosemary.
  choice: HOW TO MAKE: Pizza With Artichokes, Rosemary and Goat Cheese
Ingredients:
1 1/4 ounce packaged dry yeast
1 cup lukewarm water
2 1/2 cups high-gluten flour
1 teaspoon salt
4 tablespoons olive oil
1 pound baby artichokes
1 clove garlic, green part removed, minced
1 medium onion, sliced
1 tablespoon rosemary leaves
Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
3 ounces goat cheese
3 tablespoons pine nuts.
  choice: Cover and leave until doubled in volume.
  choice: If working by hand, combine the flour and salt and place on a smooth work surface.
FIRST COMPUTER-GENERATED SENTENCE:
targets: Stir in the garlic and rosemary.
multiple_choice_targets:
HOW TO MAKE: Pizza With Artichokes, Rosemary and Goat Cheese
Ingredients:
1 1/4 ounce packaged dry yeast
1 cup lukewarm water
2 1/2 cups high-gluten flour
1 teaspoon salt
4 tablespoons olive oil
1 pound baby artichokes
1 clove garlic, green part removed, minced
1 medium onion, sliced
1 tablespoon rosemary leaves
Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
3 ounces goat cheese
3 tablespoons pine nuts.
Make the pizza dough.
Combine the yeast with one-quarter cup of the water.
Cover and leave until doubled in volume.
If the mixture does not rise, throw it away and use a fresh package of yeast.
If working by hand, combine the flour and salt and place on a smooth work surface.
Stir in the garlic and rosemary.
Cook for another minute.
Add the artichoke hearts, stir and cook for an additional 3 minutes.
Remove from heat and transfer to a bowl.

DOCUMENT:
There was once a prince of the land. He was loyal to the king, loved by the citizens, and adored by princesses the world around. He was just, fair, and spoke with an air of confidence to draw even the most independent of ears. The prince didn't need to be told this, but was consistently told by all around him. Everyone hung on his every word as he spoke. On one occasion, the prince came into the square to speak to his public. People stopped their daily affairs and gathered around the pedestal the prince instructed his knights to set up. They listened intently as he talked about the kingdom's future. "I am the prince of the land," said the prince. "My name is Prince Alrik."

  choice: "My name is Prince Alrik."
  choice: On one occasion, the prince came into the square to speak to his public.
  choice: "I am the prince of the land," said the prince.
  choice: The prince didn't need to be told this, but was consistently told by all around him.
  choice: Everyone hung on his every word as he spoke.
  choice: They listened intently as he talked about the kingdom's future.
  choice: He was loyal to the king, loved by the citizens, and adored by princesses the world around.
  choice: He was just, fair, and spoke with an air of confidence to draw even the most independent of ears.
  choice: People stopped their daily affairs and gathered around the pedestal the prince instructed his knights to set up.
FIRST COMPUTER-GENERATED SENTENCE:
targets: They listened intently as he talked about the kingdom's future.
multiple_choice_targets: There was once a prince of the land.
He was loyal to the king, loved by the citizens, and adored by princesses the world around.
He was just, fair, and spoke with an air of confidence to draw even the most independent of ears.
The prince didn't need to be told this, but was consistently told by all around him.
Everyone hung on his every word as he spoke.
On one occasion, the prince came into the square to speak to his public.
People stopped their daily affairs and gathered around the pedestal the prince instructed his knights to set up.
They listened intently as he talked about the kingdom's future.
"I am the prince of the land," said the prince.
"My name is Prince Alrik."

DOCUMENT:
Youth, they say, is wasted on the young. Whoever "they" is probably never saw a corpse like this. At first, it was just another way to get high. The kids called it "Burst" for that burst of energy and euphoria. Like a lucid dream, Burst gave you control over the Universe, and didn't kick so hard as you came down.  "Jesus, what the fuck is that? "I turn toward the voice, and see a fresh-faced rookie choking back vomit while the tech is lining up photos of something sticky. In fact we're all here now: Answering questions about religion (or whatever) has become one thing at best—a huge part from our upbringing or experiences in school? Or perhaps my memories are too strong right then/now?
